**Crime and Punishment**  
**Translatorâ€™s Preface**

A few words about Dostoevsky might help English readers understand his work.

Dostoevsky was the son of a doctor. His parents worked very hard and were very religious, but they were so poor that they lived with their five children in just two rooms. The mother and father spent their evenings reading aloud to their children, usually from serious books.

Even though Dostoevsky was often sick and weak, he finished third in his final exams at the Petersburg school of Engineering. There, he started his first work, "Poor Folk."

This story was published by the poet Nekrassov in his magazine and received a lot of praise. The shy, unknown young man suddenly became somewhat famous. A bright and successful future seemed to be ahead of him, but those hopes soon faded. In 1849, he was arrested.

Although he was not a revolutionary by nature or belief, Dostoevsky was part of a small group of young men who met to read the works of Fourier and Proudhon. **PAGE SUMMARY:** Dostoevsky, despite his promising beginnings as a writer, faced arrest in 1849 for his involvement in discussions against censorship.
